title: UK's largest payday lender QuickQuid collapses into administration
text:
The UK’s payday lending industry appeared to be all but over yesterday after QuickQuid collapsed into administration following thousands of complaints from customers.

QuickQuid, which is owned by US parent Enova, will be shut after it failed to reach a deal with regulators over an avalanche of compensation claims made against it.

Along with other payday lenders, the firm has faced accusations that it preys on people in financial difficulties by granting them small loans at sky-high interest rates.

It is feared the company’s closure will leave thousands with complaints against it in limbo, with regulator the Financial Ombudsman Service yesterday unable to confirm whether they could still be pursued [File photo]

QuickQuid offers loans of up to £1,000 for new customers – or £1,500 to those returning – and its website quotes annual percentage rates (APR) up to 1,300 per cent.

Last night it was confirmed that Grant Thornton had taken control of QuickQuid’s trading company, CashEuroNet UK, as administrator.

It is thought to have been facing as many as 10,000 complaints, many of them from borrowers given loans they could not afford to repay.

QuickQuid offers loans of up to £1,000 for new customers – or £1,500 to those returning – and its website quotes annual percentage rates (APR) up to 1,300 per cent

QuickQuid’s demise follows the recent collapse of rivals Wonga and The Money Shop, which followed a government crackdown on the amount payday lenders can charge.

John Cullen, business recovery partner at accountancy firm Menzies, said: ‘In the face of growing regulatory pressures, the curtain appears to be drawing on the payday lender market.’

Martin Lewis, of MoneySavingExpert.com, said: ‘As with the demise of Wonga, if QuickQuid does go, in the long run it will not be a cause for tears. These debts for the vast majority of customers were hideously over-expensive and unhelpful.’

It is feared the company’s closure will leave thousands with complaints against it in limbo, with regulator the Financial Ombudsman Service yesterday unable to confirm whether they could still be pursued.

Grant Thornton said those who have taken out loans from QuickQuid should carry on making repayments.

David Fisher, boss of Enova, said the firm had ‘helped millions of hard-working people get access to fast, trustworthy credit’.

He blamed a ‘challenging and uncertain regulatory environment’ in the UK for QuickQuid’s woes.

authors: Matt Oliver City Correspondent For The Daily Mail
